blueprintr 0.0.4

A Walkthrough of blueprintr

Source: vignettes/blueprintr.Rmd
blueprintr.Rmd

blueprintr is a companion to drake that focuses on documenting and testing tabular data. Whereas drake manages the workflow execution, blueprintr defines a collection of steps that need to be run in a drake workflow.

Basic Use

The first, and recommended, step is to attach blueprintr to your R session with library().

library(blueprintr)

In a drake project, all packages that you want attached are declared in a "packages.R" file. This library(blueprintr) command should go there.

blueprintr is built around ‚Äúblueprints.‚Äù Our first blueprint will be a blueprint for mtcars:

blueprint(
  "mtcars_dat",
  description = "The famous mtcars dataset",
  command = {
    mtcars
  }
)
#> <blueprint: 'mtcars_dat'>
#> 
#> Description: The famous mtcars dataset
#> Metadata location: '/Users/runner/work/blueprintr/blueprintr/blueprints/mtcars_dat.csv'
#> 
#> -- Command --
#> Drake command:
#> {
#>     mtcars
#> }
#> 
#> Raw command:
#> {
#>     mtcars
#> }

All blueprints have

  • A name (the first argument) for the target dataset.
  • A description or brief summary of what the target is. Can be NULL.
  • A command, which is a quoted statement that has the code for building this target.
  • A metadata location, which is a path to where the target metadata is saved.
the blueprint name is ‚Äúmtcars_dat‚Äù rather than ‚Äúmtcars‚Äù. If the two had the same name, drake would determine that the blueprint has a circular dependency (it depends on itself). To avoid this, blueprints should not have the same names as global variables, like mtcars.

To get this loaded into a drake plan, we need to attach it to an already existing plan using

attach_blueprint(plan, blueprint)
attach_blueprints(plan, ...)
attach_blueprints accepts ‚Äútidy dots‚Äù, so if you have a list() of blueprints, you can ‚Äúsplat‚Äù all of those blueprints into attach_blueprints like attach_blueprints(plan, !!!list_of_blueprints)

If you don‚Äôt have an existing plan, you can create one with

plan_from_blueprint(blueprint)

For now, we‚Äôll use an already existing plan, which is probably what you‚Äôll have most of the time.

attach_blueprint(
  existing_plan,
  blueprint(
    "mtcars_dat",
    description = "The famous mtcars dataset",
    command = {
      mtcars
    }
  )
)
#> # A tibble: 8 x 3
#>   target           command                                                format
#>   <chr>            <expr_lst>                                             <chr> 
#> 1 initial_vector   runif(1000)                                          ‚Ä¶ <NA>  
#> 2 squared          initial_vector^2                                     ‚Ä¶ <NA>  
#> 3 mtcars_dat_init‚Ä¶ {     mtcars }                                       ‚Ä¶ <NA>  
#> 4 mtcars_dat_blue‚Ä¶ blueprintr::blueprint(name = "mtcars_dat", command = ‚Ä¶ <NA>  
#> 5 mtcars_dat_meta‚Ä¶ blueprintr::create_metadata_file(mtcars_dat_initial, ‚Ä¶ file  
#> 6 mtcars_dat_meta  blueprintr::read_metadata(mtcars_dat_meta_path)      ‚Ä¶ <NA>  
#> 7 mtcars_dat_chec‚Ä¶ blueprintr::eval_checks(all_variables_present(mtcars_‚Ä¶ <NA>  
#> 8 mtcars_dat       blueprintr::accept_content(mtcars_dat_checks, mtcars_‚Ä¶ <NA>

blueprintr creates five ‚Äústeps‚Äù (targets) per blueprint:

Target name Description
{blueprint}_initial The result of running the blueprint‚Äôs command
{blueprint}_blueprint A copy of the blueprint to be used throughout the plan
{blueprint}_meta A copy of the dataset metadata ‚Äî if the metadata file doesn‚Äôt exist, it will be created in this step
{blueprint}_checks Runs all checks on the {blueprint}_initial target
{blueprint} The built dataset after running some cleanup tasks

At this point, you‚Äôre able to run drake::make() on this plan!

when writing other targets in your plan, it is advised to not refer to the {blueprint}_initial step since it could have problems which are discovered in the {blueprint}_checks step.
